content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Its good
I think you might preset the keyboard direct on the IDE, as an no-QWERTY user, i struglle to undestood all these caracthere that i dont use to use

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem statement is well defined .. it has good logic and can be done within the CoC timeframe

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really fun challenge that is unlike any I've seen before. Easy to solve but takes a bit of time to think about. :)

Nice challenge, Solved it in Python quite quickly:
w = input().lower()
R=["`1234567890-=","qwertyuiop[]\\","asdfghjkl;'","zxcvbnm,./"]
print(["No","Yes"][any(all(i in r for i in w)for r in R)])

I think 16 test cases is a bit overboard (I've never seen so many for a clash). Also, I think you should say:
<<Line 1:>> lower-case word to check

You imply that all letters are lower-case because you say no "shift + button" but I think it would be nice to make it extra clear. Approving regardless. :)
Why not give the rows as input? Then you could validate against some different layouts. :)

Test and Validator for the first case (salad) are the same.
According to the guidelines "Each validator must* differ from the corresponding test"

This was a fun CoC,. While reading the comments, I saw ou added lots of improvements which render the problem quite easy for Fast mode (Adding the keyboard layout for example), but as a Code Gold exercise, it becomes even better.
However, I suggest you make the test cases more diverse because there are many pairs of test cases that look almost alike and might confuse beginners.
I can't wait to stumble upon this once while clashing :D
Would be interesting to allow Shift as a key on its specific row (so 'Z' is typed using a single row, but 'Q' takes two rows).
"True" and "False" as outputs are not fair, since not all languages can directly print them from a boolean. "Yes" and "No" would be better.

I think you should write something about uppercase.
In the statement is nothing written about if word can contain uppercase characters.
In the Testcases is only the Validator for Long One with an uppercase character. This is maybe a mistake. If not, I think you should change also the Testcase.
In your code I can see that you only test for lowercase characters.

So is the output, if word contains uppercase character always False?
Is it just the same as a lowercase character?
Or can you just use uppercase letters from row 3, because Shift is in it?
I think that you should make this clear.

And one more little thing: I would write in the Constraints that 0 < the Length of word ≤ 128
That makes it shorter and better to understand

Not everyone uses a *US* qwerty keyboard. I'm on a standard *UK* qwerty keyboard and: 
" is on the top row
@ # and ~ are on the ASDF row
\ and | are on the ZXCV row

I don't think it's fair to expect users of other keyboards to know the locations of all the symbols on a US keyboard.
Either specify which symbols are on which row in the statement, or provide 4 additional inputs with lists of keys.


If a symbol or uppercase letter (not one on the ZXC line) needs a Shift key, can it really be typed with buttons from a single row?
unfair ... i have no time to get qwerty layout on internet while clashing ....
I've added the keyboard layout in the statement.
Good points. I've added the keyboard layout to assume, removed the uppercase letters and the symbols typed with shift and updated the test cases.
Agreed, I've updated the statement and the test case.
I don't think any of the mainstream languages at least print it like True or False
Then I'll have to give the position of the 'Shift' in the example layout and I think this will confuse the audience.
Fixed
Seconded. This would make this Clash even more international (i.e. we use AZERTY in France, but you could also have non-English QWERTY layouts).
Thanks, I've added the "lower-case" clarification in the statement.
I'll give it a try
Python do. It's enough to made it unfair.
I mean, it's a bit like saying ruby is unfair, because it's generally shorter
No. A language giving an advantage to his users is pretty different of a problem that give an advantage to the users of a language.
Both problems come down to the same thing, a language being better suited for a specific purpose. You can still change your language if you feel like it will make it shorter

I agree with the fact that players have to choose the best suited language depending of the problem. 
But. The statement itself doesn't have to give advantage to a language. Like it was said a lot of time since the CoC was added on CG: It's "Clash of Code", not "Clash of Python".
Furthermore, a lot of CoC players don't know multiple languages, and don't use python.

I've changed the output format. 
I agree, if the person doesn't know python will have a little disadvantage, but such scenarios may happen often for different languages, maybe we need a more strict(fair) rule for 0/1 output.
